Crime and Punishment

There’s nothing wrong with my reasoning. Everything I’ve figured out this past month is clear as day—like math. But, oh my God! I just can't bring myself to do it! Why am I still stuck here? 

He stood up, looking around like he was surprised to be in this spot, and headed toward the bridge. He was pale, his eyes were lit up, and he felt drained. But suddenly, he could breathe easier. It was like he had dropped a heavy weight that had been crushing him for ages. Relief washed over him. “Lord,” he prayed, “show me my path—I’m done with that cursed dream of mine.”

As he crossed the bridge, he took a calm look at the Neva River and the sun setting in a fiery sky. Even though he was weak, he didn’t feel tired. It was like an infection in his heart had finally burst. Freedom! He was free from that spell, that obsession!

Later, when he thought back to that time and everything that happened, he was struck by one detail. It seemed like a fateful moment, even if it wasn’t that special on its own. He could never figure out why, when he was exhausted and should’ve taken the quickest route home, he chose to go through the Hay Market instead. It didn’t make sense; it was a detour he didn’t need to take.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The protagonist experiences a profound sense of relief and newfound freedom after renouncing his dark desires and reflecting on a seemingly fateful detour.
